courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Methodology of Social Science Research
courses.description: This course deals with the methodology and skills in studying social science subjects, with particular focus on politics, economics and sociological disciplines. It provides training for students to handle a variety of data presented in either verbal, numbers or graphical fashion, alongside with the skills to present their analysis in a reader-friendly fashion. It also familiarizes students with some basic data-processing skills and functions supported by SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences). This course covers, but not limited to, i) Basic research skills: Literature Review and citations ii) Quantitative data analysis: Basic Statistics, Simple Regression Model and SPSS; iii) Qualitative data analysis: Surveys, interviews, focus groups, field works and discourse analysis, iv) Analysis and Interpretation; v) Internet Research methods. This is a required course for GLBS students.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOCI2003
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Field Studies and Methodology of Social Science Research
courses.description: This is a required course for GLBS students and a continuation of GLBS2002. Students will be given the opportunities to visit a destination outside of Hong Kong, to taste the real-world implications of Globalization to different communities. The objective of this course is multifold: (1) to practice the skills acquired from GLBS2002 via field studies; (2) to train students’ ability in comparing the impact of Globalization to different regions, (3) to provide opportunities for students work in group; and (4) to enhance students’ relationship with the teaching staffs. The field studies will take place under the supervision of one or more teaching staffs of this Programme. Students are required to join all lectures and workshops before the field studies. They are required to submit an individual report afterwards.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GLBS2001
courses.course_syllabus: Designed by the course supervisors
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Geopolitics and the World in Media
courses.description: This course introduces a number of important issues happening around the World today - provided with some basic level of analysis and understanding of some key terms often come across in studying features of Globalization - by using materials from news media. It aims to equip students with better foundation of facts as well as some basic presentation skills. This course is going to cover, but not limited to, i) historical background of the contemporary world order; ii) basic knowledge about the geopolitical distribution; iii) overview of the agendas concerned by different regions; iv) introduction and comparisons of the political systems and institutions undertaken in the major powers. This is a required course for GLBS students and is conducted in Chinese.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.title: Use of English in Global Studies

Students will receive intensive trainings about the usage of English, including the vocabulary expansion, speaking and writing for academic purposes, so that it can enhance their capabilities to cope with various topics come across from different classes. Coursework is specifically designed and particularly relevant to international and global affairs.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: English Speech and Presentation for the Global Market
courses.description: This is a required course dedicated for GLBS students in order to enhance their communication skills and competitiveness in the Global market. Special attention will be given to interpersonal communication, pair/group discussion, oral presentations and speaking improvement activities.

2. participate in discussions by expressing himself/herself clearly and fluently and with a good degree of confidence and spontaneity

3. give clear descriptions and explanations on a range of topics which are either concrete or abstract in nature

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Theories and Practices of International Relations
courses.description: This course provides an overview of International Relations (IR) theory, the concepts and approaches often adopted in studying the discipline. It aims to familiarize students with different theoretical frameworks and key issues encountered by the globalizing society. This course covers a wide array of topics, but not limited to, i) the mainstream IR theories, provided with some case studies; ii) analysis of some key theoretical literatures and introduce their respective historiographical perspectives, including the Clash of Civilizations and its critics; iii) in-depth studies on some selected thematic issues; iv) International Relations theory and Globalization.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Global Governance and Principles of International Law
courses.description: This course aims to cope with the subjects of Global Governance from the perspective of Public International Law. It examines the interaction among nation-states, non-state-actors and the International institutions and analyzes how they come to terms with each other under the Global context, provided with some case studies. This course covers, but not limited to, i) concepts of global governance; ii) key concepts from different sources of International Law, e.g. the Law of the Sea ; iii) international organizations and global governance including the Bretton Woods system; iv) state, sovereignty, and globalization; v) role of Hong Kong and China in Global Governance.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
1) Martin Dixon, Textbook on International Law, 6th edition, (Oxon: Oxford University Press, 2007);
2) Margaret P. Karns & Karen A. Mingst, International Organizations: the Politics and Processes of Global Governance, 2nd edition, (Boulder: Lynne Rienner Publishers, 2009).

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: World Economies: Theories, Practices and New Development
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to both macroeconomics and microeconomics with a view of the international economy by looking at some major theories and case studies. It aims at equipping students with the capacity to analyze the impacts of economic and social policies. It studies the implications of national policies and international agreements as well. This course covers, but is not limited to, i) macroeconomic theory, ii) microeconomic theory, iii) theories of international economics, iv) relationship between trade and politics, and v) international trade policy in developing nations, not least the emerging markets and BRICS.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 – Orientation and Overview

Week 2 – How Markets Work

•Obtain basic understanding of interdependence and gains from trade.

•Graphically and numerically analyze the impact of changes in key market factors.

•Homework 1

Week 3 – How Markets Work 2

•Understand key concepts of market - competition, supply, demand, place, and elasticity.

•Understand how government interacts with markets using price controls and taxation.

Week 4 – Market and Welfare

•Understand the concepts of consumer surplus, producer surplus, and market efficiency as well as market failure.

•Understand costs of taxation, and the concept of dead weight loss.

Week 5 – International Trade and Welfare, and Economics of Public Sector

•Understand the impacts, and determinants of trade.

•Understand the concepts of externalities, solutions to externalities, and public goods.

Week 6 – Public Goods and Common Resources, and Firm Behavior and the Organization of Industry 1

•Understand the importance of property rights.

•Understand various costs of production, including the long-run and short-run costs.

Week 7 – Firm Behavior and Organization of Industry 2

•Understand competitive market and profit maximization.

•Understand the concepts of competitive markets, monopoly, and welfare cost of monopolies.

Week 8 – Firm Behavior and Organization of Industry 3

•Public policy towards monopolistic competition, and oligopoly.

Week 9 – Income Inequality, Macroeconomic Data, Measuring Costs of Living

•The measurement of inequality and policies to reduce poverty.

•Understand how a nation’s income is measured.

•Understand how the costs of living are measured.

Week 10: The Real Economy in the Long Run

•Understand the concepts of economic growth, and how public policies affect economic growth.

•Understand how financial institutions work, and the concept of the national income accounts.

•Understand the roles of the central banks, how money is supplied, and role of government in fiscal policies.

•Understand the basic concepts of open economy macroeconomics.

Week 11: Money and Prices in the Long Run

•Understand the monetary system.

•Understand the classical theory of inflation and monetary policy.

Week 12: Debts and Economic Crises

•Understand the concepts of open economy macroeconomics.

•Understand the linkage between debts issues and macroeconomic crisis.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings: 1) Paul R. Krugman, Maurice Obstfeld & Marc Melitz, International Economics: Theories & Policy, 9th edition, (Boston: Pearson Education, 2011)

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Understanding Global Cities and Urban Space
courses.description: The course aims to present the effect of globalization on global cities and urban space. This is a required course for students majoring Global Studies without substantial background in social science disciplines on society and urban space use. The course shall first provide students with basic ideas and concepts relevant to topics relating to modern society and control of public space in social science disciplines. The second part of the course shall present fundamental concepts and theoretical perspectives to the study of globalization and its consequence on urban development and global changes. Such course design aims to build students’ conceptual thinking and imagination on the global world so they shall use such capacities to evaluate issues and debates shaped by the effects of globalization on the expansion of global cities and functions of public space in GLBS4501 Analyzing Development and Change in Global Cities and Urban Space.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After students have met basic requirements of this course, they are expected to demonstrate abilities to:

1. describe main theoretical approaches in explaining the effects of globalization on urban development

and change

2. use urban ethnographic method to analyze identity and (sub)culture in social organizations in their

assignments and group projects

3. provide personal and critical reflection on redevelopment projects in Hong Kong or any part of the

world, then to make their own decisions about the extent of personal engagement in collective movements

for future urban development in communities where they belong to
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to course organization, topics, expectation and assessment

Basic concepts and perspectives in the study of society and urban space

Part I. Societal Effects of Development and Change in Global Cities

a) Societal effects of globalization: basic concepts

b) Economic, cultural and societal aspects of globalization

c) Theoretical foundations of urban and suburban forms in development and change

• Classical foundations

• Urban Ecology: the Chicago School

d) Methodology studying urban development and changes in social organization: urban ethnography

e) Urbanism as a way of life

• Demography and cities

• Social inequality in global cities

• Migration within and across borders

• Global civil society

Part II. Political Interactions of Space Use and Functions in Global Places

a) Spatial effects of globalization: basic concepts

b) Theoretical foundations and evolution of spatial structures of capitalist urbanization

c) The new urban restructuring:

• The globalization of urbanization

• The neoliberalization of urbanization

d) Resistance: Oppositional forces in urban restructuring under the global era

• The global politics of globalization: global movements and social changes

• Contestation of the rights on cities spaces: ‘glocalization’ as a solution?

e) Cities spaces and the global ‘war on terror’

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: The Rise of China in the Global Context I: Diplomacy, Trade and Soft Power
courses.description: This course looks at the "Rise of China" from the perspective of Global Governance and specifically sheds light on its diplomatic, trade and cultural relations with others in the Global Community. It provides a critical analysis on the transformation of Chinese foreign policies since the establishment of the People's Republic of China and the momentum behind this change of practices. This course covers, but not limited to, i) the History and evolution of Chinese foreign policies; ii) the analytical framework of policy-making process in China, particularly in handling foreign and security affairs; iii) its foreign relations with both the developed and developing nations; iv) its booming economy and integration with the global economy; v) assessment on the rhetoric of "Peaceful Rise" and "Charm Offensive" with reference to the Confucius Institute.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
1) Marc Lanteigne, Chinese Foreign Policy: an introduction, (Oxon: Routledge, 2013);
2) Andrew J. Nathan & Andrew Scobell, China's Search for Security, (New York: Columbia University Press, 2012).

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Understanding Global Issues from Movies
courses.description: This is an elementary level course which examines how media industries have projected the global agenda items through movies. It enables students to understand how the difference in cultural/national/social background would impact on the perceptions of people, in spite of the same objects and referents. In some occasions, such interpretations may reflect a certain degree of bias and hence jeopardize integrity of the facts. It is particularly helpful to students who haven't studied any courses from the Global Studies Programme in understanding relevant topics.
courses.course_syllabus: Designed by the course instructors
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Sports and World Politics
courses.description: This course examines the relationship between Sports and World politics, in particular about the evolution of global political economy through various sports events like the Olympic Games and World Cup. Taking different sport games as case studies, this course aims to raise attention about some ongoing debates on the global political arena, e.g. Separatism, regional identity, global democracy. It also encourages students to think critically how politics and sports are mutually shaping each other.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to demonstrate abilities to:

1) Understand the relationship between Global Politics and World Sports

2) Understand sports from a political structure and landscape

3) Analyze various global issues through sports events.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Music in the Global Society
courses.description: This course examines aspects of popular music culture and its industry in shaping global order and influencing the global society. It introduces the dominant theoretical approaches to the study of music, including musicology, cultural studies and sociology. By illustrating the relationship and conflict between industry giants and indie musicians in light of the approaches taught, students are able to appreciate the global and local dynamics in shaping our global society. Societal trends and phenomena affecting the global order that are driven by music, such as the 60’s US folk movement and the recent K-Pop enthusiasm, will be lastly examined.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After students have met basic requirements of this course, they are expected to demonstrate abilities to:

1. describe and contrast main theoretical approaches explaining the relationship of music and society

2. draw critical assessment on the significance of music and its industry in the global society on the basis of theoretical approaches introduced in this course

3. apprehend the global and local dynamics in the making of music culture and social order

4. be able to examine societal trends and phenomenon with reference to music and its culture
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction to the course: organization, topics and evaluations

II. Theoretical approaches to the study of music

1. Musicology

2. Cultural studies theories

3. Sociology

III. Making Music: Transnational corporations versus local musicians

1. Production

2. Consumption

IV. Case studies: Changes to the global order driven by music

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Hong Kong's External Relations and Chinese Foreign Policies
courses.description: This course aims to illustrate how Hong Kong has exercised its influence in the global society after the handover of Sovereignty in 1997, despite the constraints imposed by the Basic Law, and how they conform to, or at odds with, the grand strategy of People's Republic of China (PRC). This course approaches the subjects from individual, domestic, and systemic levels of analysis. It covers topics ranging from the transnational economic network of Hutchison-Whampoa to legal case which exhibit clashes of the code of practice between the Special Administrative Region (SAR) and its motherland. This course is conducted in Chinese.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, the student will

1. be able to identify a broad range of issues towards Hong Kong’s relations with the international community and its interaction with China’s foreign policies

2. be able to recognize and describe different views on the influence of Hong Kong in the global society under the constraints imposed by the Basic Law and the influence of People’s Republic of China (PRC)

3. be able to analyze and elaborate different views from individual, domestic, and systemic levels

4. be able to reflect independently and critically on the position and role of Hong Kong as a Special Administrative Region (SAR) and its motherland
courses.course_syllabus:

PART I: CORE CONCEPTS AND BACKGROUND

Hong Kong, Basic Law and sub-state governance

China’s Grand Strategies in the Globalized World

Hong Kong’s external relations in the 1900s

PART II: HONG KONG AS A FACILITATOR

Hong Kong’s billionaires and the Track II diplomacy

Hong Kong Multinational Corporations (MNCs) and China’s financial globalization

Hong Kong and multilateralism: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), Bo’ao forum, World Trade Organization, and World Health Organization

Hong Kong-Singapore relations: the tale of two cities

Hong Kong-Taiwan relations

The Kitty Hawk incident: Hong Kong and Sino-US relations

The Philippines Hostage Crisis: Debate for Sub-sovereignty

The Congo Case: the clashes of legal systems

Democratization: Hong Kong and the myth of “foreign-interference”?

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Korea and the World: Politics, Economy and Culture
courses.description:
This course examines the connection between Globalization and South Korea after World War II. It is also interested in accounting for the changes of political, economic, social and cultural aspects of
South Korea in the last few decades and the transformation of the attitudes towards Globalization in South Korean society. This course will cover a variety of topics ranging from i) brief overview of
the historical development of South Korea since WWII; ii) driving forces and features of the economic developments, iii) their foreign policy concerns, iv) the characteristics of the traditional cultural
identities, v) the recent Korean-wave phenomenon; vi) opportunities and challenges brought by Globalization to Korean society.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: European Union and the World
courses.description: This course adopts various approaches to unravel the complexity of the ongoing integration project in Europe. Alongside the theoretical analysis, this course sheds light on the connection between Europe and the World. It will cover topics including, but not limited to, the Common Foreign and Security Policy, the EU Law, as well as EU’s contribution to Global Governance.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Japan and Global Political Economy
courses.description: This course examines the connection between Globalization and foreign policy-making of the country after World War II. It will cover a variety of topics ranging from the rationales behind the ups-and-downs of its economy, towards the Japanese perceptions towards Sino-Japanese relations and even the country’s role in the Global society.

2. enhanced the knowledge of the interplay between Globalization and domestic politics in Japan
3. acquired the skills of critical thinking
4. acquired the techniques to apply theories and perspectives into daily lives

Japanese political structure, peace constitution and foreign policy-making
Japanese economic globalization after WWII

Japan’s relations with Great Power: US, Russia and China
Japan’s regional policy in East Asia

Japan and Global Governance
Assessment of the impact of Globalization on Japanese foreign policy, society and culture

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Colonial Governance in Hong Kong and the British Empire
courses.description: This course studies the interaction between Hong Kong, at a time when it was still under British colonial rule, and the international community. Themes include the features of early globalization, the connection between colonial Hong Kong and the collapse of the Qing Dynasty in China, Hong Kong under the influence of Japanese Imperialism and the Cold War, and Sino-British relations. It also examines how various international norms have found their way to shaping the tiny colony, which has stood in stark contrast with Mainland China, to whom Hong Kong's sovereignty was returned in 1997.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, the student will

1. be able to identify a broad range of issues towards of the impact of British colonialism to Hong Kong

2. be able to recognize and describe the history of Hong Kong’s external relations in the modern era reflecting the features of early Globalization and the international norms, including free-trade policies, popular nationalism, rise of anti-colonialism, Transnational Corporations and democratization

3. be able to analyze and elaborate the features of early Globalization and the international norms from historical, political, economic and socio-cultural dimensions

4. be able to reflect independently and critically on the position and role of Hong Kong under the British colonial rule and post 1997 with sovereignty returned to China

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Global Civil Society and Operation of Non-Governmental Organizations
courses.description: This course looks at the operation of Global Governance from a bottom-up approach. It aims to provide a combination of major theories and debates behind global civil society, together with the practices of advocacy networks, social movements and non-governmental organizations coalitions. This course covers the following topics, but is not limited to, i) Features and Operations of Global Civil Society (GCS), with particular concerns on the operations of NGOs; ii) Themes and Issues which GCS pushed forward in the recent decade, and assessments over their performance; iii) Role of GCS in Global Governance, e.g. its cooperation with the United Nations in addressing global food crisis; iv) Challenges and Opportunities open to different International NGOs and transnational advocacy groups; v) Case-studies, e.g. Anti-WTO protests in Seattle; GONGOs in China, etc.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: ICT and the Global Order: Internet, Smartphone and E-Governance
courses.description: This course tackles specifically on the growing importance of Information Technology and e-Governance in recent decades. Besides studying the significance of the proliferating information flow and accessibility, this course studies how the virtual society has hence been connected to the physical life, not least its effects on us. The following topics will be covered in this course, but they are not confined to: i) Rise and Features of E-commerce, E-politics and E-Governance; ii) IT Products and trade policies; iii) IT, Social Media and Political influence; iv) Cyber-security and Cybercrime; v) Case Studies on digital currencies and virtual states.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Developmental Study: Poverty, Inequality and Welfare of the World
courses.description: This course aims at providing a critical and theoretical overview of the issues, processes, and responses central to poverty, inequality and welfare around the World. It relates the challenges encountered by these developing states with the dark-sides of the Globalization. This course covers topics including, but not limited to, i) Theoretical understanding of Development and Poverty; ii) Development and Modernization: Asia as examples; iii) Dependency and World Systems Theories: Latin America as examples; iv) Colonization and Cultural Imperialism; iv) Equality in various aspects: Gender, Labour, Food and Wealth; v) International Institutions in ameliorating/aggravating poverty.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

1) Jeffrey Haynes, Development Studies, (London: Polity Press, 2008);
2) Robert Potter et al, Geographies of Development: An Introduction to Development studies, 3rd edition, (Essex: Pearson Education, 2008)

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Global Development: Markets, States, Societies and IOs
courses.description: This course aims to provide in-depth analysis of inter-disciplinary global issues using basic principles of economics. This course is built on the introductory economics with respect to the International Political Economy (IPE) framework i.e., the roles of markets, states, society, and International Organizations (IOs) will be elaborated throughout the course. Hence, prior knowledge of introductory economics and the IPE theory are recommended. The course covers growth and human capital theories, and case studies of how policies are developed and implemented to address global issues. Issues discussed in the course include human capital development, economic development and widening inequality, education, social protection, human rights, emergencies and responses including both natural disaster and man-made conflicts, aging population, disadvantaged populations such as disabilities and ethnic minority, energy, and environment.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students deepen understanding of

a. Various global development problems in the contemporary world, and

b. Theories for economic development and human capital development.

2. Policy and practice of global issues are understood through a case-study approach.

3. The roles of markets, states, society and international organizations to address global issues are appreciated.

4. A habit of critical thinking is developed.

5. The skills to apply the knowledge into daily lives are acquired to act as a change maker to address global issues locally.

courses.title: Islamic and Christian Culture in the Global Order: Religion, Society and Economy
courses.description: This course focuses on the relations among the world religions and their contribution to the formation of new identities of class, gender, ethnicity, nation and economic development in the global context. This course covers two major sets of world religions, Islam and Christianity with emphasis on their popular expression rather than formal theologies.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Advanced Methodology of Social Science Research
courses.description: This course is built on the core course on GLBS2002 Methodology of Social Science Research (or any other basic methodology courses offered by other departments at a similar level). While the introductory course covers the basics of social science research methods, this course offers more practical and advanced social research techniques by covering descriptive statistics, uni- and multi-variate regression analysis, and introduction of cost-benefit analysis and other intermediate quantitative methods. Students will acquire new quantitative skills through learning a statistical program (e.g., SPSS). Students are requested to write a term paper using quantitative methods. The quantitative methods learned in this class are used in all policy arenas, including the public and private sectors. The course content prepares students for academic and professional careers that use empirical analyses, particularly relevant to those who are interested in working for governments, NGOs or policy consultation units after graduation.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Traditional Security: Military, War and Peace
courses.description: This course introduces the academic field of strategic studies and security studies by referring to a few theoretical analysis and their practices in reality. This course also sketches out the ongoing debates about security, war and peace in International Relations for the better understandings of strengths and limitations of extant frameworks. The topics covered in this course include, but do not limit to, i) Basic understanding of military history and strategies, e.g. Clausewitz and Sun Tzu; ii) Theoretical approaches to International Security; iii) Traditional security challenges faced by nation-states and its evolution; iv) Alliance system and other responses to such challenges; v) Assessment of the level of threats imposed by these traditional security challenges.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: New Security Challenges: Terrorism, Ethnic Conflicts and Human Trafficking
courses.description: This course furthers the studies of security challenges to the so-called "Non-Traditional Security" field which becomes more outstanding under Globalization by undermining the role of states in terms of the ability to mobilize force. Unlike another course emphasizing states as the primary actors in Global Security, this course puts more emphasis on how individuals, non-state actors and International Organizations have taken up the responsibilities to uphold the Global Order. This course puts special focus on: i) Terrorism, ii) Ethnic conflicts, and iii) other human security challenges including immigration, energy, health problems.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Political Economy of Africa
courses.description: This course examines the political economy of nation-states in the Sub-Saharan region and review how Globalization has aggravated the outstanding developmental problems. This course will cover issues such as colonialism, ethnicity, ideology, political cultures, global capitalism, and foreign interventions, in order to provide a comprehensive analysis to study the factors impeding development in Africa.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to demonstrate abilities to:

1) Analyze the political economy in Africa from different perspectives

2) Describe the most outstanding challenges that impede developments in Africa

3) Describe the impact of Globalization on former colonies

4) Compare and contrast the African cases with other regions

5) Rethink critically what the Africans need the most in order to achieve sustainable development

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Analyzing Global Cities and Urban Space
courses.description: The course is an extension of GLBS3105 Understanding Global Cities and Urban Space. It examines the extent of globalization effects that shape social, political and cultural meanings of space and place. The course is divided into two sections. The first section gives emphasis to the collective effect of globalization on everyday life in global cities. Social problems of urbanization, technological change in global cities, and mass culture of consumption are topics to be examined in this section. Political shaping of urban space use is another emphasis of this course. Both sections shall use issue-based approach to illustrate concepts covered in GLBS3105. Each lecture shall cover a collective phenomenon in the global cities. The purpose is to use an issue to illustrate the making of everyday life in global cities is a consequence of globalization. At the same time, local society and communities are remaking the global landscape of social and cultural space.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GLBS4103.
courses.course_syllabus:
COURSE INTRODUCTION & OVERVIEW

Introduction to the course: organization, topics and assessments

Revision on theoretical approaches covered in GLBS3105

PART ONE Societal Effects of Globalization on World Cities

a) What is a global city? How and why do we rank cities?

b) Urban development and city icons

c) Social inequalities and global cities

d) Environment as a global problem

e) Technology and social change in a global world

f) Mass consumption in the city: McDonalization and Disneyization

PART TWO Political Landscape of Urban Space in Global Cities

a) Social and political space of city: theoretical dimensions

b) Global governance: Debate and critics

c) Spatial politics of public square: Tiananmen and Victoria Park

d) Where is non-place: McDonald and airport

e) Beyond capitalism: Re-constructing the spatial value of industrial ruins

f) Shopping under global capitalism: Spatial debate of shopping mall

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Education and Development in a Global Perspective
courses.description: This course introduces general functions and effects of education in development. The course covers and reviews main theoretical approaches in the field of education and development, such as modernization theory, human capital theory, dependency theory, liberation theory, and new institutionalist theory. Drawing on these theoretical approaches, the course further discusses collective effects of education on national development in industrialized world and developing world. At the same time, the course gives emphasis to examine educational changes and reforms that shape and reshape national educational policies across nations over time. Such organization of this course aims to invite students to think critically about the societal value of schools and schooling experiences and its relevance as a development project in both first and third world societies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After students have met basic requirements of this course, they are expected to demonstrate abilities to:

1. describe main theoretical approaches explaining the relationship of education and development

2. make comparisons of educational development in industrialized and developing worlds

3. use cross-national and longitudinal data to outline global educational patterns

4. use formal documents of international organizations as reference while comparing national policies on education

5. draw critical assessment on the meaning and significance of education and development on the basis of theoretical approaches introduced in this course

6. provide personal biographies of their own schooling experiences and reflect to what extent the collective effects of education on development have organized their individual life courses
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction to the course: organization, topics and evaluations; What is the relationship between education and development?

II. Theoretical interpretations of the collective effects of education and development

III. Worldwide organization and expansion of education

A. Education for development in the industrialized world

B. Education for development in the developing world

IV. Educational reform and change in a global perspective

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Global Capital Flows: Multinational Corporations, Global Property Market and FDI
courses.description: This course examines the major dynamic of economic globalization, global capital flows, and its impacts to the foreign direct investment, global financial market and also the Property market around the World. It also sheds light on the issue of money laundering and other financial crimes which has been accelerated, if not made possible, by Globalization. This course covers the following topics, but is not limited to, i) the Global financial order: Relationship between trade, finance and MNCs, ii) the Operation of different financial markets, e.g. Properties, Derivatives, Bonds, Stocks and FX Market; iii) an in-depth study of the financial institutions and assessment of the mode of Governance, e.g. Credit-Rating Agencies, Central Banks, BIS, G8, G20 and the Bretton Woods System; iv) Possibilities and Challenges of Global Financial Governance in the 21st Century.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: The Rise of China in the Global Context II: Internationalization of the Chinese economy
courses.description: This is an advanced-level course which is designed mainly for students planning to enhance their understanding in the contemporary China under globalization. This course will provide a comprehensive analysis of the market transition of Chinese economy and China’s increasing role in the world economy after 1978. It covers topics including, but not limited to, i) China's strategies in promoting internationalization; ii) China and Global Economic Governance, iii) challenges and possibilities of China's internationalization strategies. Students are recommended to register this course only after having studied GLBS3106 or relevant subjects.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: GLBS
courses.title: Selected Topics in Global Studies I
courses.description: This course conducts selected studies on some important topics in Global Studies. The topics may include issues such as globalization, global politics, economic and financial development and social and cultural evolutions. The focus of the course may vary according to the area of expertise of the instructor and the interests of the class.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, the student will:

1. have a solid grasp on the history and theories related to Global Studies

2. recognize the plurality and diversity of academic debate on Global Studies

3. acquire a basic understanding of the multi-faceted range of Global Governance

4. comprehend current affairs critically and analytically
